title: Midfield, Highland
text:
Midfield is a remote <a href="Hamlet%20%28place%29">hamlet</a> on the <a href="North">North</a> <a href="coast">coast</a> of <a href="Scotland">Scotland</a> in <a href="Sutherland">Sutherland</a> in the <a href="Highland%20%28council%20area%29">Highland Council Area</a>. It is a mile <a href="south">south</a> of <a href="Tormade%20Point">Tormade Point</a> and just over a mile north of <a href="Talmine%2C%20Sutherland">Talmine</a> and the <a href="Achininver%20Beach">Achininver Beach</a> and said location's Lodge are located within Midfield. Midfield is 4 miles from the <a href="A838%20road">A838</a> and 5 miles from the larger settlement of <a href="Tongue%2C%20Highland">Tongue</a>. Midfield is also labelled as a <a href="crofting">crofting</a> settlement according to the Gazetteer for Scotland. Midfield is a part of the <a href="Melness">Melness</a> area.
There are no pubs in Midfield.
Access.
The settlement is far away from most decently sized streets and towns with the nearest big road being the <a href="A9%20road%20%28Scotland%29">A9</a> nearly 40 miles away. The only access to the hamlet is by a small road that links to the <a href="A838%20road">A838</a> and passes through <a href="Melness">Melness</a> and <a href="Talmine">Talmine</a>, despite being on the coast, there is no proper nearby <a href="port">port</a> access with Port Vasco within the hamlet not being anything more than a mere tourist attraction.
Etymology.
The name comes from basic <a href="English%20language">English</a> quite literally meaning the middle of a field. Although potentially written as Middlefield at first, over time it would've been shortened to Midfield. Meanwhile, Achininver the name of the nearby beach comes from the <a href="Scottish%20Gaelic">Scottish Gaelic</a> word Inbhir which means the mouth of a river meaning the mouth of the <a href="River%20Achin">River Achin</a>. Unlike most town names in <a href="Scotland">Scotland</a> named after the river they sit on the mouth of such as <a href="Inverness">Inverness</a>, the word Inver comes after the river name.
